question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
There exist constants $p$ and $q$ so that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ the vectors $\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c},$ $2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c},$ and $p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c}$ are always collinear.  Enter the ordered pair $(p,q).$
inference:
The vectors are collinear if and only if the determinant of the matrix
$$\begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c} & 2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c} & p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c} \end{bmatrix}$$
is equal to zero. Since $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c}$ are arbitrary, we can write this determinant as
$$\begin{vmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -2 & 3 \end{bmatrix} & \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 & -4 \end{bmatrix} & \begin{bmatrix} 0 & p & q \end{bmatrix} \end{vmatrix}$$
$$=\begin{vmatrix} 1 & -2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 & -4 \\ 0 & p & q \end{vmatrix}$$

$$\ =(1)\begin{vmatrix} 3 & -4 \\  p & q \end{vmatrix} - (-2)\begin{vmatrix} 2 & -4 \\ 0 & q \end{vmatrix} + (3)\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & p \end{vmatrix}$$

$$=3q+4p=0$$

$$ \Rightarrow \qquad p = -\frac{3}{4} q$$

So the ordered pair is $(p,q)=\boxed{\left(-\frac{3}{4}q,q\right)}$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{\left(-\frac{3}{4}q,q\right)}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
The line through $\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c}$ and $2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}$ can be parameterized by
\begin{align*}
&\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c} + t((2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}) - (\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c})) \\
&= (1 + t) \mathbf{a} + (-2 + 5t) \mathbf{b} + (3 - 7t) \mathbf{c}.
\end{align*}To get an expression of the form $p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c},$ we want the coefficient of $\mathbf{a}$ to be 0.  Thus, we take $t = -1,$ which gives us $-7 \mathbf{b} + 10 \mathbf{c}.$  Hence, $(p,q) = \boxed{(-7,10)}.$

question:

$$=\begin{vmatrix} 1 & -2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 & -4 \\ 0 & p & q \end{vmatrix}$$

$$\ =(1)\begin{vmatrix} 3 & -4 \\  p & q \end{vmatrix} - (-2)\begin{vmatrix} 2 & -4 \\ 0 & q \end{vmatrix} + (3)\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 0 & p \end{vmatrix}$$

$$=3q+4p=0$$

$$ \Rightarrow \qquad p = -\frac{3}{4} q$$

So the ordered pair is $(p,q)=\boxed{\left(-\frac{3}{4}q,q\right)}$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{\left(-\frac{3}{4}q,q\right)}$. I hope it is correct.

ground_truth:
The line through $\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c}$ and $2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}$ can be parameterized by
\begin{align*}
&\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c} + t((2 \mathbf{a} + 3 \mathbf{b} - 4 \mathbf{c}) - (\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b} + 3 \mathbf{c})) \\
&= (1 + t) \mathbf{a} + (-2 + 5t) \mathbf{b} + (3 - 7t) \mathbf{c}.
\end{align*}To get an expression of the form $p \mathbf{b} + q \mathbf{c},$ we want the coefficient of $\mathbf{a}$ to be 0.  Thus, we take $t = -1,$ which gives us $-7 \mathbf{b} + 10 \mathbf{c}.$  Hence, $(p,q) = \boxed{(-7,10)}.$
